content: Many congressional policymakers are concerned about the adequacy of the U.S. science and engineering workforce to meet various national needs. Congress has funded programs to improve STEM skills, encourage students to pursue science and engineering degrees, and provide research experiences at universities. The 115th Congress is considering legislation to promote STEM. The 115th Congress is considering legislation to promote STEM education and address U.S. S&E workforce needs through changes to immigration policies. Labor economists examine employment growth, wage growth, and unemployment rates for evidence of shortages in key S&E occupations. This report provides employment, wage, and unemployment information for various S&E occupations. The section on "Current Employment, Wages, and Unemployment" offers data on S&E workforce in 2016. The section on "Recent Trends in Employment, Wages, and Unemployment" shows changes from 2012-2016. The section on "Employment Projections, 2016-2026" analyzes future projections. "Concluding Observations" provides stakeholder perspectives for Congress to consider ensuring an adequate S&E workforce. The United States aims to have a sufficient S&E workforce for the 21st century, with varying definitions of STEM occupations. The size of the workforce depends on the occupations included, as stated by the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the National Science Board. The National Science Board's 2016 report highlighted the size of the Science and Engineering (S&E) workforce in the U.S., ranging from 6 million to over 21 million depending on the definition used. The focus of the debate on the adequacy of the S&E workforce has been on computer, mathematical, engineering, and physical science occupations. The S&E workforce includes life scientists but excludes social scientists. The S&E workforce in 2016 was approximately 6.9 million, categorized into six occupational groups including computer occupations and mathematical occupations. Scientists and engineers are crucial for U.S. technological leadership, innovation, and national defense. Congress has been concerned about the adequacy of the science and engineering workforce for over 60 years, enacting programs to support education and development in STEM fields. Some policymakers aim to increase foreign scientists and engineers in the US through visa changes. Views vary on the adequacy of the S&E workforce and related policy issues, including whether there is a shortage of scientists and engineers in the US and if the federal government should intervene. Some policymakers debate whether there is a shortage of scientists and engineers in the US and if the federal government should intervene. Views vary on the issue, with some arguing for a shortage while others believe more scientists and engineers are needed regardless. Increasing the number of U.S. scientists and engineers can boost innovation, economic performance, and job creation, even if there is no shortage currently. S&E degrees provide valuable skills for various occupations, and government interventions to address shortages may lead to inefficiencies. Government efforts to increase scientists and engineers may lead to inefficiencies in the labor market, such as an oversupply of S&E graduates and lower salaries for job seekers. Long-term workforce projections are unreliable, resulting in mismatches between education and market needs due to unexpected changes in technology, prices, and retirement behavior. Shortages in certain industries or occupations, including new and emerging S&E fields like nanotechnology, may exist due to various factors such as changes in prices, retirement behavior, and government policies. The labor market will resolve these needs through wage adjustments, increased labor supply from students earning S&E degrees, and substitution of alternative inputs. Shortages in industries like nanotechnology may lead to adverse consequences and require government intervention to increase supply. Industry claims of shortages are driven by a desire to lower labor costs and replace older workers with younger, lower-cost ones. The real issue is a skills mismatch, not a shortage of people. Expanding immigration to address shortages in the S&E workforce, particularly in information technology, can help by matching the specific skills needed by employers with those held by workers. This can benefit the U.S. economy by utilizing foreign scientists and engineers, reducing the loss of U.S.-educated foreign nationals, and dampening market signals that would otherwise drive more U.S. students into science and engineering. Policies to increase foreign scientists and engineers in the US may depress wages, increase unemployment, and discourage American students from pursuing STEM careers. Federal efforts are needed to improve STEM education for US students to compete globally. The adequacy of U.S. student STEM knowledge is not accurately reflected in standardized tests compared to other nations. This leads to differing opinions on federal government roles in fostering the S&E workforce, including increasing students pursuing S&E degrees, admitting foreign scientists, promoting diversity in science and engineering, improving K-12 STEM education, and enhancing career counseling for high school students. Congress is considering ways to enhance U.S. competitiveness. Congress is considering approaches to bolster U.S. competitiveness in scientific, engineering, technological, and industrial leadership.
